title: Chief Complaint
content: Right forearm fracture post direct blow during soccer, with difficulty tolerating long-arm cast.
instruction: What is the main complaint of the patient, give a one liner detailed note. Only include hand related surgery and issues.

title: History of present illness
content: Ori Blumenfield, a 47-year-old right-hand dominant corporate lawyer, sustained a direct blow to the right forearm while playing soccer on 9-14-2025, resulting in an immediate sensation of injury. He presented to urgent care where X-rays confirmed a closed right ulna shaft fracture. He was referred to Andrew Weiss, who placed him in a cast. He is currently being evaluated for ongoing difficulty tolerating the long-arm cast, which extends above the elbow, limiting his ability to wash himself and perform self-care. He expresses concern about enduring the cast for the expected duration. He denies any numbness, tingling, or neurological deficits. He has not experienced any prior similar injuries. The fracture is minimally displaced with good alignment, and no instability is noted at the wrist or elbow. He is otherwise asymptomatic except for discomfort related to the cast. He is motivated to return to normal function and is seeking further management options. He has no known allergies and is not on any medications. He is employed and reports that the injury is significantly impacting his daily activities and quality of life. He has discussed the injury with his primary care provider and the referring surgeon. He is concerned about the length of immobilization and potential need for surgery. He is compliant with follow-up and is seeking a definitive treatment plan.
instruction:
Provide a detailed summary of the patient's current illness based on their report. Include a thorough description of symptoms, noting their onset, duration, and severity or intensity. Discuss any changes or developments in symptoms since their onset and identify factors that may exacerbate or relate to these symptoms, such as specific activities, foods, or medications. Document any prior treatments or remedies the patient has attempted, noting their efficacy. Describe how these symptoms impact the patient's daily activities, overall well-being, and quality of life. Capture information about any individuals mentioned by the patient, specifying their relationship and any pertinent interactions or conversations related to the illness.

Doctors Preference:
1) Do NOT use 'the patient', use the persons gender ex: 'he or she ...' 
2) End the sentence with a period.

title: Imaging
content: X-rays taken on September 15th, 2025, were reviewed with the patient. Two views of the right forearm were ordered, taken, and reviewed, demonstrating a minimally displaced mid-shaft ulna fracture. No instability noted at the wrist or elbow. Old X-rays were also reviewed. CT scan was reviewed for Becky Lawrence, showing increased space at the radiocapitellar joint, indicating possible recurrent instability from a torn ligament. Four views of the bilateral wrists with Rolando views were ordered, taken, and reviewed for Richard Frank, showing no fracture or dislocation, with moderate degenerative changes at bilateral trapezium and carpal joints and mild thumb IP arthritis. Normal shoulder X-rays were obtained for Steve Smith.

title: Plan
content: Place patient in a short-arm splint with waterproofing to allow showering. Recommend close follow-up with X-rays. Discuss cast care and red flags. Recommend continued conservative management given good alignment and minimal displacement. Re-evaluate in two weeks for X-rays and clinical progress. Advise patient to report any worsening pain, swelling, numbness, or discoloration immediately. Educate on signs of compartment syndrome and neurovascular compromise. Return to clinic in two weeks for X-rays and reevaluation.
instruction:
Detail the healthcare provider's plan of action to manage the patient's condition, specifying treatments, medications (include ongoing medications briefly), procedures, therapies, lifestyle modifications, referrals to specialists, patient education on condition and medications, and recommendations for counselings or support services.

Also in the end provide the plan of action for the individual conditions. And return the follow-up duration as a number.
When presenting the follow-up, format the sentence as: "Return to clinic in X days/weeks/months."
